tossups.question: Description acceptable. Extensive dashcam footage and records from text messages were included in a 2018 Oscar-nominated documentary short film about this event titled "In the Absence." After this event, the message "one small movement, big miracles" was widely hung in café windows. People angry about this event displayed a yellow bowtie-shaped ribbon on a black background. A film at the BIFF festival about this disaster led to 9,000 artists being placed on a government (*) blacklist. A charge of failing to prevent a "right of life" during this disaster was included alongside an over-reliance on a "spiritual adviser" in impeachment charges brought in 2017. Most of the 306 victims of this disaster attended Danwon High School. For 10 points, identify this 2014 tragedy when hundreds of students drowned en route to Jeju Island.
tossups.answer: Sewol ferry disaster [accept anything involving a South Korean ferry shipwreck; accept anything mentioning MV Sewol; accept anything involving a shipwreck near Jeju Island before the end; prompt on shipwreck by asking "in what country?"]

tossups.question: This formalism can be derived from an equivalent martingale measure that yields the replication of terminal claims by using Girsanov's theorem. The common derivation of this formalism begins by choosing a function that varies only with underlying value and time and applying Itô's lemma; from there, it can be solved using the Feynman–Kac ("cots") formula. This formalism predicts that one of its parameters does not vary with DTM and thus has a flat surface, but, empirically, (*) graphs show a concave-up curve called a "volatility smile." This model's instantaneous log returns vary with constant drift, thus following geometric Brownian motion. This model assumes that there are no opportunities for delta-hedging or arbitrage. For 10 points, Robert Merton won a Nobel Prize for helping two economists develop what partial differential equation used to price European options?
tossups.answer: Black–Scholes model [accept Black–Scholes–Merton model] (DTM is the time to maturity.)

tossups.question: Jacob Zionts criticized the hollowness of “blockchain democracy” on Active Citizen in this city, which misleadingly used the label “renovation” for a vote to tear down five-story apartment blocks. Kiosks outside this city's metro stations were torn down to build Central Circle, a 54-kilometer light rail system that now makes this city only the 13th-most congested in the world. Prior to 2012, the rough border of this city was the outer MKAD ring road. In 2010, the Society of the Blue Buckets in this city protested VIPs who place (*) migalki on their cars to rush through traffic. Commuters in this city were outraged in 2001 when a woman stabbed a subway-riding stray dog. A cathedral that was rebuilt in this city in 2000 was the site of a 2012 guerrilla performance of the song "Punk Prayer." Online maps of this city are offered by a search company based here, Yandex. For 10 points, Pussy Riot performed in the Cathedral of Christ the Saviour of what capital of Russia?
tossups.answer: Moscow [or Moskva] (The dog was named Malchik.)

tossups.question: A Den of Geek article by James Clayton noted that this song's Italian version feels different, with new chorus lyrics meaning, "I know! Yes I know!" and the "Nessun Dorma"-inspired title "All'alba sorgerò." An official "behind the mic" video that went viral shows this song, which shifts from F minor to A-flat major, performed in 25 languages by singers like Lisa Stokke and Anaïs Delva. A Complete Set album features this song in 41 languages for international dubs. (*) Demi Lovato sang the single version of this song, which was co-written by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and won Best Original Song at the 2014 Oscars. In the movie it's from, this song ends with a woman played by Idina Menzel using her powers to slam a door after singing "the cold never bothered me anyway." For 10 points, name this breakout song from Disney's Frozen.
tossups.answer: "Let It Go" [accept foreign versions such as "Lass jetzt los" or "Libérée, délivrée" or "La Den Gå"]

tossups.question: Stephen Simpson's group has reviewed data on this problem from British Columbia's VENUS cabled observatory. Researcher Michel André has helped EU countries abate this problem with a program called LIDO. One proposed mitigation to this problem is Q-MPAs ("Q-M-P-A’s"), special zones free from deterrent and harassment devices. In 1994, environmentalists protested an ATOC experiment to test the effects of this problem, which may cause Physeter ("fai-SEE-ter") to compensate by "masking." Rosalind Rolland's annual survey found significantly lower stress hormones when this problem was briefly reduced in a natural experiment following 9/11 in the (*) Bay of Fundy. This problem may impair schooling behavior and can lead to mass strandings following war games. For 10 points, anti-submarine devices contribute to what problem that makes it hard for whales to use echolocation ("echo-location")?
tossups.answer: ocean noise pollution [or marine noise pollution; accept equivalents that involve making loud noises in the world's oceans or seas or other bodies of water; prompt on anthropogenic noise pollution by asking "where?"; prompt on ocean pollution; before the end; prompt on answers like whales not being able to hear each other; accept Acoustic Thermometry of Ocean Climate; in place of "ocean" prompt on parks or protected areas and accept marine parks or marine protected areas]

tossups.question: In one novel from this country, the protagonist refuses to remove her yellow coat after the death of a character whose judo magazine subscription is never cancelled. An Iraqi immigrant to this country wrote a Kafkaesque novel whose protagonist is forced to always keep track of the five title objects by EU bureaucrats, titled Two Blankets, Three Sheets. In a novel from this country, a rural family's life is disrupted when the protagonist prays that her brother be taken instead of her pet (*) rabbit; that International Booker Prize-winning novel is titled The Discomfort of Evening. A city in this country titles a novel in which a composer plagiarizes "Ode to Joy" and engages in a plot to euthanize his rival, the newspaper editor Vernon Halliday. For 10 points, name this home country of Marieke Lucas Rijneveld (“ma-REE-kuh LOO-koss RYE-nuh-felt”), the setting of the conclusion of Ian McEwan's ("muck-YOO-in’s") Amsterdam.
tossups.answer: The Netherlands [or Nederland; anti-prompt on Holland] (Two Blankets, Three Sheets is by Rodaan al Galidi)

tossups.question: The expat community in this country was scandalized by an essay about a reporter's illiterate door-to-door garbage collector and gossip network that was later included in Peter Hessler's book The Buried. In a 2020 book, Noah Feldman argued that the same degree of agency was demonstrated by this country’s January 25th and June 30th movements. A leader of this country earned the nickname "spare tire" for being the second choice behind an engineer who was disqualified for running for president in 2012. It's not Turkey, but protesters in this country hold up four fingers to make the (*) Rabaa Sign to protest a 2013 massacre. A Google exec from this country set up a Facebook page supporting Khaled Said. Members of Tamarod ("ta-MAH-rud") helped bring down a democratically-elected president of this country affiliated with the Muslim Brotherhood. For 10 points, name this country ruled by Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
tossups.answer: Egypt [or Arab Republic of Egypt; or Jumhūrīyat Miṣr al-ʻArabīyah]

tossups.question: In 2017, Yelena Mizulina introduced a bill to decriminalize first offenders who committed this crime in Russia. China passed a law prohibiting this type of crime after an incident with the founder of the language training company Crazy English. Preventing this crime is the main purpose of the Istanbul Convention, which was rejected as unconstitutional in Bulgaria. A 2012 reauthorization bill granted undocumented immigrants who were victims of this crime temporary visas. The 1996 (*) Lautenberg Amendment prevented people convicted of this type of crime from obtaining a firearm. Joe Biden co-sponsored a 1994 law that established an office at the Department of Justice to prosecute this type of crime; since 2012, that bill has also covered same-sex relationships. For 10 points, name this type of crime whose victims once found refuge in "battered women's shelters."
tossups.answer: domestic violence [or DV; or domestic abuse; or intimate partner violence; or family violence; prompt on violence against women or femicide; prompt on abuse]

tossups.question: In an essay for The Fabulist, this author described living above a homeless man who liked to wear Marsden Hartley shirts, whom she later found out was the artist Richard Hambleton. A character created by this author is shot by Nina Simone for trying to make a documentary about her. In this author's most recent novel, Gordon Hauser, who wrote a thesis on "the fateful concept of the American Adam," teaches classes at a facility modeled on Chowchilla. The protagonist of her debut novel is given the chance to use the Spirit of Italy to set the female land speed record. In that same novel, the narrator meets New York artists such as Sandro Valera and earns the nickname Reno owing to her place of origin. In her most recent novel, a mother named Romy Hall is (*) serving a life sentence. For 10 points, name this American author of The Flamethrowers and The Mars Room.
tossups.answer: Rachel Kushner

tossups.question: A real estate headquarters in this city mimics a clamshell with two circular, convex façades covered by glass skin. Buro Happold imitated vernacular cooling screens for this city's Landmark Tower. Idris Khan designed this city's war memorial, the "Oasis of Dignity." A museum in this city is dominated by the "rain of light" generated from the 8,000 medallions in its central dome and was the first universal art museum to open in the 21st century; that museum is located on its so-called "Island of Happiness." A sinusoidal steel arch bridge and a Performing Arts Center in this non-Vilnius city were designed by (*) Zaha Hadid for a planned Guggenheim complex. Leonardo's Salvator Mundi was briefly slated for this city's Jean Nouvel-designed satellite of the Louvre. This site of the Sheikh Zayed Mosque is served by Etihad Airways. For 10 points, name this capital of the UAE.
tossups.answer: Abu Dhabi [or Abū Ẓaby; accept Khalifa City] (The first sentence is about the Al Dar Headquarters. The "Oasis of Dignity" is the Wahat Al Karama.)

tossups.question: CAFOs ("KAY-fohs") used organic compounds of this element like ROX and Atoxyl to control coccidiosis ("cox-id-ee-OH-siss") and histomoniasis before a 2015 FDA ban. HG-AA and ICP-MS can speciate this element into two inorganic acids that may be treated by iron oxide adsorption in La Pampa, Argentina, and Terai, Nepal. North Korea has stockpiled chemical weapons containing this element bound to chlorine, like the vomiting agent adamsite and the blister (*) lewisite. Bioremediation of this element may exploit its hyperaccumulation by the Chinese brake fern. A hyped-up 2010 Science paper dubiously claimed that the bacterium GFAJ-1 incorporated this element into its DNA in Mono ("MO-no") Lake. Brown rice syrup can expose babies to unhealthy levels of this element, which causes blackfoot disease in Taiwan and contaminates groundwater in Bangladesh. During glycolysis, this phosphorus analog inhibits ATP formation. For 10 points, name this toxic metalloid.
tossups.answer: arsenic [or As; accept organoarsenic compounds or organoarsenicals; accept arsenous acid or arsenic acid; accept arsanilic acid or aminophenyl arsenic acid or aminophenyl arsonic acid; accept dimethylarsenic acid; prompt on Roxarsone] (HG-AA is hydride generation atomic absorption spectrometry. ICP-MS is inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry.)

tossups.question: While visiting an ailing member of this family, the narrator of one essay does not correct nurses who confuse him with comedian Dave Chapelle. Another member of this family explains his nickname by stating, "Certain mother fuckers think they can fuck with my shit, but you can't kill the Rooster." One member of this family, fond of long walks picking up litter, is inundated with gifts like a Japanese toy "that blinks… and softly hoots when you plug him into your computer" by relatives based on a passing reference to liking (*) owls. That same member of this family frequently writes about his partner Hugh in books like When You Are Engulfed in Flames and Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim. For 10 points, name this family that includes the author of Me Talk Pretty One Day and "Santaland Diaries," as well as the actress, Amy.
tossups.answer: Sedaris [accept David Sedaris or Amy Sedaris; accept Hugh Hamrick]

tossups.question: In No Path Home, Elizabeth C. Dunn claimed that "chaos is intrinsic" to this practice's industry, explaining its 2009 failures in Khurvaleti, Georgia. A 1992 Graham Hancock book attacked this practice's "Midas touch" in projects like Polonoreste ("poh-loh-no-RESS-chee"). A 2009 book criticizing this title practice recalls an 8,000-mile motorcycle trip by Lukas Lundin to highlight road quality. Roger C. Riddell found that this practice is increasingly (*) multilateral in a book that asks if it "really works." At MC6, the WTO launched an initiative linking this practice to trade. Zambian economist Dambisa Moyo argued that bond markets could fix issues with this "dead" practice, whose agencies often operate IDP camps. In The White Man's Burden, William Easterly mocked Jeffrey Sachs for touting this practice as "the end of poverty." For 10 points, what practice transfers resources internationally?

tossups.question: AEI scholar Fred Kagan takes credit for being the "intellectual architect" of this campaign, which is the subject of the 2019 book The Last Card. In his book Dark Territory, Fred Kaplan argued that much of the success of this campaign was due to the Real Time Regional Gateway reducing delays in intelligence from sixteen hours to less than one minute. This campaign was outlined in a paper titled "The New Way Forward" and coincided with the resignation of John Negroponte as DNI. A video of two Apache helicopters engaged in this larger campaign was leaked under the title (*) "Collateral Murder." Patrick Cockburn argued that this campaign's apparent success could be entirely attributed to ethnic cleansing of Sunnis. tossups.question: SB 360, introduced into the California legislature in 2019, seeks to end a carve-out for people in this profession from California's 1990 law on mandated reporters. In a June 2019 cover story in The Atlantic, this profession's former member James Carroll argued that it should be abolished. The lawyer Eric MacLeish provided information to reporters like Robby Robinson about people in this profession for a 2001 piece that was dramatized in an Oscar-winning film by Tom McCarthy. tossups.question: An artist with this surname exhibited a gold-plated mosquito net over a bunk bed for the piece Weight, first shown at Reading Gaol ("redding jail") in 2016. A second artist with this surname staged a degree show at St. Martin's titled Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims, and, for a later show, had robots spray-paint a model dressed in white. That first artist with this surname directed a film where a colander wobbles for over 20 seconds after a police raid on the Mangrove restaurant. The song "Fashion of His Love" by (*) Lady Gaga was dedicated to a British designer with this surname at Givenchy ("zhee-von-SHEE") who committed suicide in 2010. A Turner-Prize-winning director with this surname included a long shot of a priest played by Liam Cunningham staring in his profile of an IRA member played by Michael Fassbender. tossups.question: Elizabeth Otto's book on a "Haunted" version of this institution celebrated its "gender fluidity" and "occult spirituality." In 2019, the left-wing People's Theatre group performed a public burial of this institution to protest a government-sponsored "Whole World" tour celebrating it that included a moveable replica of its headquarters. Fiona MacCarthy's much-reviewed 2019 biography of this institution's "Visionary Founder" was timed for the 100th anniversary of its founding. Nicholas Fox Weber argued that this institution's "ideals and design" were "embodied" in (*) Apple's iPhone. In 2019, separate exhibitions in Dessau, Berlin, and Weimar all commemorated this institution, many featuring works by László Moholy-Nagy ("LOSS-low mo-HO-lee-NAHJ") and Marcel Breuer. For 10 points, many 2019 memorials celebrated what German art school founded by Walter Gropius?
tossups.answer: Bauhaus [accept Haunted Bauhaus; accept iBauhaus: The iPhone as the Embodiment of Bauhaus Ideals] (The biography is Walter Gropius: Visionary Founder of the Bauhaus.)

tossups.question: The name of this film’s antagonist is used for the unstable branch of Debian OS. A Traveller's Tales game based on this film kicked players out to a minigame on glitches to get past Sega quality checks. A sequel to this film was saved by a backup that new mother Galyn Susman had saved on her home machine. The plaid shirt worn by this film's main character was intentionally chosen because it couldn't be done with previous techniques. This film was originally going to star a character named Tinny from an earlier (*) short. It was the first feature film to be supervised by a "braintrust" comprised of executives like Ed Catmull. A planned direct-to-video sequel to this film was canceled in favor of a theatrical release built with RenderMan. Plans for automatic lip syncing in this film were rejected by John Lasseter. For 10 points, name this Pixar film that introduced Buzz Lightyear.
tossups.answer: Toy Story

tossups.question: A group called WAG successfully lobbied Congress not to change conservation easement laws governing these places in the 2017 tax bill. They're not baseball stadiums, but a company called TrackMan has created high-fidelity mappings of hundreds of these places for expensive home simulation systems. These places, which occupy 2.1% of all land in Singapore, are discussed alongside the Ship of Theseus in a Revisionist History episode where Malcolm Gladwell criticizes their outrageous tax subsidies. Millennial disinterest in these places has caused more than 800 of them to close in the 2010s, often tanking (*) property values in neighborhoods built on top of them. One of these places unsuccessfully fought against Balmedie's ("ball-MED-ee’s") plans to erect wind farms off the Scottish coast and is branded for Donald Trump. For 10 points, name these places that include Augusta National.
tossups.answer: golf courses [or golf clubs; prompt on country clubs] (WAG is We Are Golf.)

bonuses.leadin: Being this type of person means "I am a hot, brilliant, funny woman who adores football, poker, dirty jokes, and burping… while somehow maintaining a size 2, because [these people] are above all hot." For 10 points each:
answer: The Cool Girl
Gone Girl
The Girl on the Train
parts: Identify this character type described by Amy in a memorable passage from a 2012 Gillian Flynn thriller.

The Cool Girl is defined in this aforementioned Gillian Flynn novel whose unreliable title character starred in the Amazing Amy books as a kid. This novel was made into a movie starring Rosamund Pike and Ben Affleck.
One of the more prominent "Gone Girl clones" was this Paula Hawkins thriller variously told from the perspective of Rachel, Anna, and Megan. It too got a film adaptation, starring Emily Blunt.

bonuses.leadin: In Of Mice and Women, Kaj Björkqvist suggests that preteen girls often exhibit the indirect "relational" form of this trait. For 10 points each:
answer: aggression [or word forms like aggressiveness; accept overt aggression scale; prompt on violence or conflict or similar answers; accept relational aggression; accept overt aggression scale]
playing violent video games [prompt on playing games; accept gaming or gamers; accept playing electronic games or playing computer games or other rough equivalents]
explore AND exploit [or word forms such as exploration AND exploitation; accept answers in either order; prompt on partial answer by asking "what is it contrasted with?"]
parts: Name this psychological trait studied with the "hot sauce paradigm" that was developed to replace electric shocks. The OAS measures its "overt" manifestations.

Many contentious studies have examined whether this activity influences childhood aggression, generally finding that a small increase in aggressive affect results from exposure to media like Gears of War.

Two answers required. Psychologists like Robert Wilson and Maarten Speekenbrink created simple video games to model this reinforcement learning dilemma. This trade-off between two contrasting verbs is often illustrated with a "multi-armed bandit" in a casino.

bonuses.leadin: Guido Gryseels ("GHEE-do grih-SEELS") has supervised an update to this country's Royal Museum for Central Africa that now has a more critical view of colonialism. For 10 points each:
answer: Belgium [or Kingdom of Belgium; or Koninkrijk België; or Royaume de Belgique; or Königreich Belgien]
Adam Hochschild
chicottes ("shee-CUT") [accept cambuk or chabuk or fimbo or sjambok or shaabuug or litupa or  imvubu or kiboko or  mnigolo]
parts: Identify this country that houses the archive of Henry Morton Stanley, who helped establish its most notorious African colony.
This author wrote about how modern-day Belgium hadn't yet come to terms with its colonial past in his book King Leopold's Ghost.
The renovated Royal Museum for Central Africa now exhibits some of these objects, a type of whip made from dried hippopotamus hides that was used to punish Africans during the colonial period.

bonuses.leadin: Crops from this country like green plums, finger limes, boab nuts, and wattleseed are increasingly marketed as "superfoods." For 10 points each:
answer: Australia [or Commonwealth of Australia]
welcomes to country [accept acknowledgments of country; or Wurundjeri Wominjeka; prompt on answers like land acknowledgments that don't include "country"; prompt on welcome ceremony]
Canberra
parts: Name this country where indigenous activists have protested a highway that will damage their sacred birthing trees. In 2020, an iron mining company in this country destroyed a gorge that had been occupied for over 40,000 years.
It is now standard for visitors to Aboriginal lands in Australia to participate in these elder-led ceremonies, which show respect for the traditional custodians of the land.

In 2009, signs reading "Welcome to [this city]: Ngunnawal ("nun-uh-WALL") Country" were graffitied to also mention the Ngambri people, from whom the name of this city derives. A "welcome to country" now opens sessions of the Parliament of Australia here.

bonuses.leadin: Sam Quinones's ("keen-YO-ness’s") book Dreamland details how Portsmouth, Ohio, became the "capital" of these places in America. For 10 points each:
answer: pill mills
oxycodone [or OxyContin]
Kentucky [or KY] (The senator is Mitch McConnell.)
parts: Give this rhyming phrase denoting a medical practice in which a doctor makes money primarily from short visits intended to prescribe opiates to patients, with or without any medical reason.
One of the top-selling products at pill mills is this strong painkiller, which is sold under brand names like Percocet. Famous people addicted to this drug include Rush Limbaugh.

This state passed a "Pill Mill Bill" in 2012 that placed restrictions on pain management centers. Sports radio host Matt Jones drove through all 120 of its counties to understand why its senior senator is so unpopular.

bonuses.leadin: An author born in this country wrote about a Norwegian-based couple named Mugdi and Gacalo whose son became a suicide bomber. For 10 points each:
answer: Somalia [or Federal Republic of Somalia; or Jamhuuriyadda Federaalka Soomaaliya] (North of Dawn is by Nuruddin Farah)
Maine [or ME]
Anderson [or Andersen; accept Cynthia Anderson or Kurt Andersen]
parts: Identify this home country of the author of North of Dawn. Zach throws a pig's head into a mosque frequented by immigrants from this country in Elizabeth Strout's novel The Burgess Boys.
The Burgess Boys is set in this state, which is the setting of Strout's novel Olive Kitteridge. Paul LePage was a controversial governor of this northeastern state.

An author with this surname profiled how Lewiston, Maine has been transformed by its Somali community in Home Now. Another author with this surname wrote Fantasyland: How America Went Haywire and hosted the radio show Studio 360.

bonuses.leadin: Angelin Preljocaj's ("on-zheh-LAN prel-jo-KAHJ's") dystopian interpretation of this ballet premiered in August 2020, the first such premiere during the COVID-19 pandemic. For 10 points each:
answer: Swan Lake [or Lebedínoye ózero] (The film is Black Swan.)
Mariinsky Ballet [or Kirov Ballet]
Matthew Bourne
parts: Name this ballet. In a psychological horror film by Darren Aronofsky, two dancers compete to star in its roles of Odile ("oh-DEEL") and Odette.

This Russian ballet company shares its name with the St. Petersburg theatre that premiered the revived Swan Lake in 1895, and still puts on many productions of the ballet today. Until 1992, it was named for an assassinated Soviet official.

This British choreographer's version of Swan Lake focuses on the Prince's relationship with his mother and depicts his secret desire for men by featuring male swans. In 2016, this choreographer premiered his ballet The Red Shoes, based on the Powell and Pressburger film.

bonuses.leadin: This film ends with the protagonist's estranged brother Andi walking away down a dilapidated street. For 10 points each:
answer: The Raid [or The Raid: Redemption; or Serbuan maut]
Indonesia [or Republic of Indonesia; or Republik Indonesia]
yakuza [prompt on Japanese gangs or organized crime or mafia] (Drunken Angel was directed by Akira Kurosawa. Outrage was directed by Takeshi Kitano.)
parts: Name this 2011 Gareth Evans film in which Rama, a police officer who practices silat, takes down the brutal fighter Mad Dog.

The Raid depicts martial arts styles that are most widely practiced in this country. The documentary The Act of Killing depicts mass killings of communists that brought power to this country’s President Suharto.

In The Raid 2, the policeman Reza works for one of these groups that opposes the Bangun outfit. Evans credited his inspirations for The Raid 2 to a genre depicting these groups; they appear in both the 2010 film Outrage and the 1948 film Drunken Angel.

bonuses.leadin: Materials scientists developing these devices have recently revisited research from the 1980s on sodium as a charge carrier. For 10 points each:
answer: lithium-ion batteries [or galvanic cells or electrochemical cells or voltaic cells or primary cells]
lithium cobalt oxide [or LiCoO2; accept lithium cobaltate or lithium cobaltite; accept LCO]
manganese [or Mn; accept manganese nodules; accept manganese dioxide]
parts: Name these devices developed by the winners of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. These ubiquitous devices have improved charge retention when they use lithium as the anode.

This compound is a common cathode in lithium-ion batteries because of its high specific energy. However, batteries using this compound are susceptible to "thermal runaway," which caused them to overheat in Boeing's 787 Dreamliners.

Cobalt can be obtained from undersea nodules of this other element, whose dioxide is used in both lithium-ion and alkaline batteries. This transition metal is mainly mined at N'chwaning ("nutch-WAH-ning") in the Kalahari in South Africa's Northern Cape.

bonuses.leadin: Erik Steiner's Spatial History Project found that, despite this city's growth, its literary settings maintained a "historical stuckness" in the West End. For 10 points each:
answer: London [accept Greater London or the London region; accept the Square Mile]
The Knowledge [or All-London Knowledge; or Knowledge of London]
Peter Ackroyd
parts: Name this city that Franco Moretti's Atlas of the European Novel contrasted with Paris in a chapter that borrows the Dickens title A Tale of Two Cities.

A 2011 Current Biology paper found that London's hackney drivers had increased hippocampal grey matter from passing this test. GPS may doom this exhaustive test, which requires cabbies to study the "Blue Book" for years.

This author argued that "the pursuit of knowledge has always been one of the city's defining characteristics" in his "psychogeography" London: A Biography. He traced London's gay history in Queer City.

bonuses.leadin: Right-wing parties in Europe such as Switzerland's Ticino League have used images of these people to rally their supporters against immigration. For 10 points each:
answer: Native Americans [or American Indians or indigenous Americans; accept more specific Native American peoples; accept The Heartbeat of Wounded Knee: Native America from 1890 to the Present; prompt on answers like warriors by asking "of what ethnic group?"; prompt on Americans]
the North [or Northern Italy; or il Nord; or Italia settentrionale; accept Lega Nord]
Dior [or Christian Dior SE; accept Dior Men]
parts: Name these people who often appear in German-language books by Karl May. David Treuer's 2019 book about the "heartbeat" of these people traces their history from 1890.

Matteo Salvini, who leads a political party named for this region of Italy, reissued an anti-immigration poster featuring a Native American in 2017. Lombardy's capital of Milan is part of this general region of Italy.
This French company, whose creative director is Kim Jones, used a slur for Native Americans to name a 2015 cologne. Bernard Arnault controls both this luxury firm and rival LVMH.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, a federal court set new guidelines requiring judges to determine whether settlements for this type of lawsuit truly benefit plaintiffs. For 10 points each:
answer: class-action lawsuits
Subway (The misleading ad was for "footlongs," which are not a foot long.)
foster care [prompt on adoption system or child protection system; accept The Lost Children of Wilder: The Epic Struggle to Change Foster Care]
parts: Identify this type of lawsuit. In 2011, the Supreme Court refused to certify membership in one of these cases that alleged systematic discrimination against women by Wal-Mart.
In 2015, lawyers pocketed 99% of the settlement paid out by this brand for misleading advertising. This brand is owned by Doctor's Associates.

A 2001 book by Nina Bernstein traced the Wilder case, a decades-long class-action suit against New York's system of this type. The New York system of this type consulted anthropologists to rule on race well into the 1960s.

bonuses.leadin: A camera, a spectrograph, and a fine guidance sensor are components of this device's Integrated Science Instrument Module, which will be protected by its Spacecraft Bus and Sunshield. For 10 points each:
answer: James Webb [or James Webb Space Telescope; or JWST]
TESS [or Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite]
Jupiter [accept hot Jupiters]
parts: Name this telescope that, following delays, is scheduled for launch in October 2021. Among other goals, it will observe the earliest galaxies formed after the Big Bang.

The James Webb telescope will also explore regions that this Explorers Program telescope identified as probable locations of exoplanets. This MIT-led successor to the Kepler mission began its all-sky survey in 2018.
TESS has observed WASP-19b and other exoplanets in a class named for "hot" versions of this gas giant, which was struck by Comet Shoemaker–Levy 9 in 1994.

bonuses.leadin: The film Lucky Grandma was partially inspired by Sister Píng, who was nicknamed the "mother" of these groups for running a New York criminal empire. For 10 points each:
answer: snakeheads [or shé tóu]
one-child policy [accept anything involving China's one-child policy; prompt on sterilization programs]
Essex [accept Essex girls; accept The Only Way Is Essex]
parts: Name these Chinese human trafficking gangs that mainly operate from Fújiàn province. One of these gangs ran the Golden Venture smuggling ship under the kingpin Guō Liángqí.
Snakeheads capitalized on a George H. W. Bush policy helping Chinese nationals harmed by this policy. Ultrasound sex identification was banned under this policy.

Snakeheads may have been involved in a 2019 tragedy in which 39 Chinese migrants froze to death in a truck in this English county. A show often abbreviated TOWIE popularized New Jersey-esque stereotypes about this county to a global TV audience.

bonuses.leadin: One book by this author imagines a future where humans are divided into "gods" and the "useless" based on whether or not they've been digitally enhanced. For 10 points each:
answer: Yuval Noah Harari
agriculture [or farming; accept more specific forms of farming like growing wheat]
body armor [or suit of armor; accept chain mail; do not accept or prompt on “weapons”] (Harari argued that turcopoles, a type of warrior in the Crusades, generally didn't use heavy armor.)
parts: Identify this author of Homo Deus, who wrote a history of humanity titled Sapiens.

Harari asserts that this invention was "history's biggest fraud," claiming that it brought more disease and a poorer diet. James C. Scott argued that civilizations only gradually adopted this practice during the Neolithic Revolution in his book Against the Grain.

Harari's first scholarly paper was a revisionist tract on the use of these objects by turcopoles. In 2019, Pierre Terjanian of The Met staged one of the largest exhibitions of these objects, centering on some owned by Maximilian I.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, voters in this city rejected a plan to build more bus routes based on the dumb idea that self-driving cars will make public transit obsolete. For 10 points each:
answer: Nashville
Koch ("coke") Brothers
municipal annexation [accept deannexation]
parts: Identify this city that may have reached peak-millennial tourism with a Master of None episode where Dev misses his flight back to New York.
Anti-transit measures have been widely funded by these conservative coal tycoons, one of whom died in 2019. They owned the second-largest private company in the US.

Elsewhere in Tennessee, the Memphis city council is considering plans to reverse this type of action for Riverbottoms and Eads. The "shoestring" or "flagpole" type of this process is often done to get around contiguous territory requirements.

bonuses.leadin: This show's 33rd season in 2019 featured episodes on N. Scott Momaday and Terrence McNally. For 10 points each:
answer: American Masters
Ursula K Le Guin [or Ursula Kroeber Le Guin]
Lorrain Hansberry [or Lorraine Vivian Hansberry]
parts: Name this biography series produced by WNET that celebrates important figures in US cultural history.
In 2019, American Masters honored this author of "Unlocking the Air." This author explored the anthropology of a sexually fluid society in "Coming of Age in Karhide," part of her Hainish Cycle.

Another recent American Masters episode featured this "young, gifted, and black" author. Robert O'Hara's Etiquette of Vigilance and Bruce Norris's Clybourne Park were two recent re-imaginings of this author's play A Raisin in the Sun.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about some art you'll find in the Brazilian art getaway of Inhotim ("een-yo-CHEEM"), for 10 points each.
answer: Chris Burden [or Christopher Lee Burden]
glass [accept blown glass or frosted glass]
Yayoi Kusama [or Kusama Yayoi]
parts: This artist created Beam Drop in Inhotim by releasing some 71 girders from a mechanical crane into a pit of wet cement. In the '70s, he held interviewer Phyllis Lutjeans at knifepoint during a live broadcast for a performance piece called TV Hijack.

Inhotim also contains the Sonic Pavilion, a circular building by Doug Aitken largely made from a type of this material. Dale Chihuly's ("chih-HOO-lee’s") Pilchuck School teaches artists how to blow works in this medium.
This artist made 500 spheres out of stainless steel for Inhotim. Starry Pumpkin, a sculpture with her characteristic polka dots, is in the collection of a newly opened museum devoted to her.

bonuses.leadin: Christoph Lengauer gave a FISH image of this woman's chromosomes to her children Deborah and Zakariyya. For 10 points each:
answer: Henrietta Lacks [or Loretta Pleasant; or Hennie Lacks; accept The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks]
Johns Hopkins University [or JHU]
Medical Apartheid [or Medical Apartheid: The Dark History of Medical Experimentation on Black Americans from Colonial Times to the Present]
parts: Name this descendant of the Pleasant family and their enslaved tobacco worker Mourning. A 2010 Rebecca Skloot book reported how scientists profited from this woman while her family remained poor.

Skloot's book led this university to name a lecture series for Henrietta Lacks, whose cancer was treated here. Telomerase discoverer Carol Greider now works at this Baltimore university that is famed for its medical school.

This 2007 history by medical ethicist Harriet Washington contextualizes Johns Hopkins's exploitation of Henrietta Lacks, arguing that Black Americans have been targeted for experimentation since colonial times.

bonuses.leadin: This author explored European debates over immigration in the 2017 best-seller Racism Explained to my Daughter. For 10 points each:
answer: Tahar Ben Jelloun [prompt on partial answer]
French [or français]
Abdellah Taïa
parts: Name this Moroccan author of The Sand Child who used testimony from former inmates as the basis for his novel This Blinding Absence of Light.

Though he mainly speaks Arabic, Ben Jelloun's novels are all in this language. Kamel Daoud wrote The Meursault Investigation in this language, based on an earlier novel written in it titled The Stranger.
This other francophone Moroccan author wrote the short story collection The Red of the Fez. The movie version of his novel Salvation Army was one of the first Arab films to feature a gay protagonist.
